Oooh! Looks like you're off to a great start with your writer's block! 

Although some features of this can be fixed, I won't blame you cuz of the shortage of ideas.

Here's an idea: what about Quinn goes around and tries to figure out what happens and what is true and what is lies? I saw a documentary once that wildlife has been healing during the pandemic (research more on that), so what if he sees species he's never seen before (like the current near extinct animals)? What if he changes the past? What if he prevents COVID from spreading? 

Writing and other forms of storytelling are basically just answering a bunch of the Five W's and the H. The most powerful one is what if. Brainstorm a bunch of scenarios that could happen. (Hint: Pick the one that has the most drama and will provide a plot twist to the reader, making them want to keep reading.) Where you left off right now already has a lot! So just pick one and elaborate on it.

To be honest, this reads like the writing process was rushed. The first and second were really good though... I'm writing a book too, already written one and decided I didn't like it (idk, sometimes I can be my worst critic), my advice is, take your time and make sure you do it well.

Shouldn't you be toggling between alternate stylesheets instead of changing a class name? You also can't "call" a variable. Why are you calling `document.body` "`darkMode`"? So if a program is made a year ago and it posted to sub page and peoples vote it then will it be there on HL ?

Nope. It depends on a lot of things:
- The date it was made (the older a program is, the more popular it has to get to start climbing the HL)
- How many votes it gets every ten mins (the HL refreshes every ten mins, and shuffles programs around depending how many votes and comments it got in those mins)

"Typically, a mushroom has six different parts. These include:

Cap: This is the part that gives the fungi its umbrella shape. The cap comes in a variety of colors, including white, brown, and yellow. In the same way that umbrellas protect us from the heat of the sun, rain, and other harsh weather conditions, the mushroom cap protects the pores or gills where mushroom spores are produced. And what are spores? Well, consider them as mushroom ‚Äúseeds,‚Äù although technically speaking mushrooms don‚Äôt have seeds.

Gills, Pores, or Teeth: Have you ever seen a fish‚Äôs gills? Mushroom gills look something like that. The gills are also called teeth or pores. The gill is a structure that appears right under the mushroom cap and produces spores.

Ring: The ring (also known as the annulus) is a partial veil that is left on the stem. It is an extra layer of protection for the spores that grow when the mushroom is still very young. When the cap grows out and breaks through the veil, the remnant is what forms the ring around the stem.

Stipe or Stem: The stipe or stem is the long, vertical part of the mushroom that holds the cap above the ground. Mushrooms growing in the wild propagate when the wind scatters the spores. For this reason, the cap and gills need to be held high enough from ground level by the stem, so that when the spores drop down, they can be carried away easily by wind.

Note that in some mushrooms, the spores grow right down the sides of the stem.  Oyster mushrooms are a good example.  Also, the way that a stem is attached to the cap can be an important clue in identifying a mushroom.  For example, a morel‚Äôs stem will attach to the inside of the hollow cap, whereas a false morel‚Äôs stem will attach to the bottom of the cap.

Volva: Mushrooms are covered in a protective veil as they grow out of the ground. This protective veil is called the volva. The mushroom pushes through the volva as it matures, leaving parts of the veil at the bottom of the stem.

Mycelium: The mycelium is a collection of thin hair-like strands that grow outward and downward into the soil in search of nutrients. The mycelium of mushrooms acts like the roots in flowering plants and can produce new mushrooms when the conditions are suitable."

Hi MJ Gaming! In order to be a better coder, you just have to _believe_ that you can do it. Do not be discouraged by the haters out there, because if you let them pull you down, you most likely will never get up.

The second thing I wanted to say is votes don't tell you if your a good coder or not. It simply tells if people like your project. (But most likely, if people vote on your projects that means they like your projects)

The (second to) last thing I wanted to say is that if you are a beginner, don't jump into, like, the stuff you see on the Hot List. The hot list is made mostly of games and advanced graphics, and if you can't do it, just remember that you will be able to one day.

The last thing you absolutely need in order to be a better coder is persistence. When you code and you can't figure something out, don't get super frustrated and give up. Instead, you can head over the the Help Requests tab and someone can help!

Good luck,
